Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5Y73-W781-JCBW-N27C-00000-00Kids'safety a priority2020-02-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:06:21ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 20,21Kids'safety a priority

I'M hugely encouraged by the landmark plans announced by the Government to give Ofcom powers to regulate social networks. The safety of children online has been compromised for too long, but this breakthrough could pave the way in setting a global standard in protecting children in their digital worlds.

The Government has shown a commitment to leading change by standing up to big tech firms. Now, Ministers must move swiftly to ensure that Ofcom is given the necessary powers, allowing it to enforce substantial fines to social networks not doing enough to prevent adults grooming children on their sites.

The internet is a wonderful place for young people to learn and social networks form a big part of their friendships, enabling them to seek support from peers. However, no longer should children be exposed to harmful content and abuse because of a slap-dash approach by tech giants.

It's why we've long called for, through our Wild West Web campaign, an independent regulator, safe accounts for children and detailed reporting on how tech firms are keeping children safe.

An estimated 90 online child sexual offences have taken place each day since the Government published the Online Harms White Paper last April. It's gone on too long and social networks must not be allowed to continue dragging their heels.

Helen Westerman, NSPCC, Service Head for Local Campaigns

urn:contentItem:60NN-H211-F03R-N3MR-00000-00Killi Featured in Dark Reading on Using "Data for Good" to Control the Pandemic2020-08-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:06:21ZLexisNexisKilli Featured in Dark Reading on Using "Data for Good" to Control the Pandemic

Aug 24, 2020( Newsfile Corp.: https://www.newsfilecorp.com/ Delivered by Newstex) New York, New York--(Newsfile Corp. - August 24, 2020) - Killi Ltd.[1] (TSXV: MYID)(OTC: MYIDF), a global leader in consumer privacy, announces that its Founder and CEO, https://www.newsfilecorp.com/redirect/DbBbU3w2Neil Sweeney[2], was featured[3] in Dark Reading magazine to discuss the tech community's chance to use "Data for Good" to fight the pandemic.The article[4] highlights current tracing applications that aren't working and outlines steps for Apple and Google to co-create a universal application using their abundant supply of data and expertise in the consumer application space.Article Highlights: Current tracing applications aren't working as a result of mismanagement, data breaches and politics.Tech leaders have the expertise to create a consumer-facing application that would have ubiquitous distribution overnight (App Store, Google Play Store) and trace the virus across borders.These companies do not want to collaborate on a universal tracing application, as it would draw attention to their current data practices.The pandemic is a rare opportunity to positively change the 'Big Tech' narrative that often focuses on antitrust, misuse of data, and perpetual data collection. Please find the full article https://www.newsfilecorp.com/redirect/4PxPtyEKhere[5].About KilliKilli is a consumer privacy ecosystem that aims to put people back in control of their data.

Killi allows consumers to take back control of their consumer data from those who have been collecting it and selling it unbeknownst to them. Available on iOS, Android as well as the web, Killi is available internationally. With Killi, consumers can opt-in and link specific personal information from various financial and social accounts that they would like to put under their control and share with companies and be compensated directly in the form of cash for its use.Download Killi here[6].FOR FURTHER INFORMATION, PLEASE CONTACT: Andrew Elinesky, CFO +1-416-904-2725Neither the TSX Venture Exchange nor its Regulation Services Provider (as is defined in the policies of the TSX Venture Exchange) accept responsibility for the adequacy or accuracy of this news release.Forward-Looking and Other Cautionary StatementsThis news release may contain "forward-looking statements" within the meaning of applicable securities laws, including, but not limited to, the Company's financing plans. urn:contentItem:60NV-43G1-DYTM-9128-00000-00Killi Featured in Dark Reading on Using "Data for Good" to Control the Pandemic.2020-08-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:06:21ZLexisNexisKilli Featured in Dark Reading on Using "Data for Good" to Control the Pandemic.

Commentary from Neil Sweeney, Founder and CEO of Killi, on the opportunity for the tech community to use data to fight the novel coronavirus.

New York, New York--(Newsfile Corp. - August 24, 2020) - 0x20 Killi Ltd. (TSXV: MYID)0x20(OTC: MYIDF), a global leader in consumer privacy, announces that its Founder and CEO, Neil Sweeney, was featured in Dark Reading magazine to discuss the tech community's chance to use "Data for Good" to fight the pandemic.

The article highlights current tracing applications that aren't working and outlines steps for Apple and Google to co-create a universal application using their abundant supply of data and expertise in the consumer application space.

Article Highlights:

* Current tracing applications aren't working as a result of mismanagement, data breaches and politics.

* Tech leaders have the expertise to create a consumer-facing application that would have ubiquitous distribution overnight (App Store, Google Play Store) and trace the virus across borders.

* These companies do not want to collaborate on a universal tracing application, as it would draw attention to their current data practices.

* The pandemic is a rare opportunity to positively change the 'Big Tech' narrative that often focuses on antitrust, misuse of data, and perpetual data collection.

Please find the full article here.

About Killi

Killi is a consumer privacy ecosystem that aims to put people back in control of their data. Killi allows consumers to take back control of their consumer data from those who have been collecting it and selling it unbeknownst to them. Available on iOS, Android as well as the web, Killi is available internationally. With Killi, consumers can opt-in and link specific personal information from various financial and social accounts that they would like to put under their control and share with companies and be compensated directly in the form of cash for its use.

Download Killi here.

urn:contentItem:60NN-8X31-JCNX-318K-00000-00Killi Featured in Dark Reading on Using Data for Good to Control the Pandemic2020-08-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:06:21ZLexisNexisKilli Featured in Dark Reading on Using Data for Good to Control the Pandemic

Link to Image

Link to Story

Killi Featured in Dark Reading on Using "Data for Good" to Control the PandemicCommentary from Neil Sweeney, Founder and CEO of Killi, on the opportunity for the tech community to use data to fight the novel coronavirus.New York, New York--(Newsfile Corp. - August 24, 2020) - Killi Ltd. (TSXV: MYID) (OTC: MYIDF), a global leader in consumer privacy, announces that its Founder and CEO, Neil Sweeney , was featured in Dark Reading magazine to discuss the tech community's chance to use "Data for Good" to fight the pandemic.The article highlights current tracing applications that aren't working and outlines steps for Apple and Google to co-create a universal application using their abundant supply of data and expertise in the consumer application space.Article Highlights:

Current tracing applications aren't working as a result of mismanagement, data breaches and politics.

Tech leaders have the expertise to create a consumer-facing application that would have ubiquitous distribution overnight (App Store, Google Play Store) and trace the virus across borders.

These companies do not want to collaborate on a universal tracing application, as it would draw attention to their current data practices.

The pandemic is a rare opportunity to positively change the 'Big Tech' narrative that often focuses on antitrust, misuse of data, and perpetual data collection.

Please find the full article here . About KilliKilli is a consumer privacy ecosystem that aims to put people back in control of their data. Killi allows consumers to take back control of their consumer data from those who have been collecting it and selling it unbeknownst to them. Available on iOS, Android as well as the web, Killi is available internationally. With Killi, consumers can opt-in and link specific personal information from various financial and social accounts that they would like to put under their control and share with companies and be compensated directly in the form of cash for its use.Download Killi here .FOR FURTHER INFORMATION, PLEASE CONTACT:
Andrew Elinesky, CFO

The problem with this is that up until now, the 30-plus years of data architecture that have been created have been done so without actually collecting consumer consent. And so these government regulators are putting more and more pressure on these larger companies to ensure that they're actually getting consumer consent, and it's leaving an individual gap in the market. ...

urn:contentItem:60NC-1NB1-JB20-G2YK-00000-00Killi Ltd at SNN Network Virtual Conference - Final2020-08-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:06:21ZLexisNexis080520a13360681.781Killi Ltd at SNN Network Virtual Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* Neil Sweeney

Killi Ltd. - Founder, Chairman, President & CEO

Presentation

OPERATOR: Greetings, and welcome to the Killi; webinar. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Mr. Sweeney. Thank you. You may begin.

NEIL SWEENEY, FOUNDER, CHAIRMAN, PRESIDENT & CEO, KILLI LTD.: Hi, everybody. Let's just dive right into it. I'm sure all of you have been listening to a number of different presentations over the last 2 days. So I'd like to introduce you to Killi, K-I-L-L-I. Ticker symbol in Vancouver is MYID and it's MYIDF in the U.S.

So before we get started, let's kind of talk specifically about kind of the overall investment thesis. I think before we're all investors, we're consumers first. And I think if you think about the 3 most dominant stories that have been in the headlines over the last 2 or 3 weeks, first and foremost, clearly, COVID. And specifically, this concept of COVID tracing has been top of mind for everybody. Last week, we saw the four horseman from Amazon, Google, Facebook and Apple in front of Congress, answering questions around antitrust and data. And then lastly, this week, dominating has been the storage, specifically around Microsoft and Tik Tok. But while these stories have been dominant over the last 2 weeks, what people are failing to kind of realize is that, this has nothing to do with antitrust and it has nothing to do with the actual pandemic. Really what the bigger issue here is this concept of what all these stories have in common is the idea of data and more specifically, around privacy. And when you're thinking about data and privacy, it's really about consumer privacy and consumer control of privacy. So these 3 trends, whether it's data privacy, consumer control or antitrust or big tech, at the end of the day, it still comes down to who is collecting this data on these individual consumers.

So for us, what we believe is that data and privacy will be the largest macro trend of 2020 and 2021. And this is similar to what we've seen in years past, whether it was around blockchain or even around cannabis. And I think the stories that I kind of have highlighted is evidence of this ever kind of growing trend. And so with this in mind, who are the public companies that are really operating in this space. And I think you're going to be hard-pressed to find another company like Killi, who is really leading the chart specifically around this.

So a little bit more about this market. I think when you ask individual consumers specifically about whether or not they know if data is being collected, although most say, yes, but most have really no understanding as to how much data is actually being collected or what the value is. As an investor, you're likely -- you're unlikely aware that you are actually worth $500 per month per user in North America, and you're growing at an average rate of about 30% per year. How does that happen? When you log in using your Google browser or you log into Facebook or you use Spotify, this is a perpetual data collection. And your consumer data is going over the fence to these individual firms. It's the oxygen of these individual platforms, and this has been going on and building for years and years and years. So whereas these companies continue to actually amalgamate and collect increasingly more data, they're actually turning that data around and actually monetizing. Hence, the reason for the increase in the actual rate.

Now the important piece about this is that what's driving the increase in the rate is fidelity of data. The higher the fidelity or the more private the data, the more valuable it is. This, as a byproduct, though, has actually caught the attention of the global privacy regulators, specifically around the world. So some of you might be familiar with privacy laws that came into effect in Europe called the General Data Rights Protection Act. It came into effect about 1.5 years ago. Most recently, this came to the United States in the form of the California Consumer Privacy Act, which sort of hit the shores of the West Coast on January 1, 2020.

In short, what this means is that in order to use people's data going forward, you must have explicit consent from the consumer. The problem with this is that up until now, the 30-plus years of data architecture that have been created have been done so without actually collecting consumer consent. And so these government regulators are putting more and more pressure on these larger companies to ensure that they're actually getting consumer consent, and it's leaving an individual gap in the market.

So with that in mind, though, there is really no company -- there are really no companies operating in the world today that are actually allowing you, as a consumer, to actually gather control of your data from all of these various different platforms, have visibility specifically on what data these companies have and actually have visibility on what actual value of this data is. And most importantly, whether or not you, as a consumer, should be compensated, we think that this is sort of the larger trend that's actually happening.

So with Killi, at its core, these are the tools that we're actually building. We are building consumer controls for data. So we are creating a platform to allow you to take your Facebook data, your Google data, your credit card data and pull it all together in one central source, controlled and owned by you. As a byproduct of that, you have transparency on all of the data that's out there. And should you decide to share that and be willing to monetize and will -- be willing to share it with brands, agencies, companies and platforms. Rather than Facebook, Google and others being compensated for the use of your data, we are redistributing this wealth back to the individual consumer. So we think that giving consumers back control of what's rightfully theirs, while also paying them in an environment where we have 15% unemployment and the economic situation is not that great, is sort of -- is a trend that we think is going to help move, not only the visibility of our company, but actually the stock as well.

So how the mechanism works is you can either download this product as an application from the Apple or Google stores. You can also access this from your browser by logging in, putting in a password. Once inside of the platform, you can pick and choose and decide which individual accounts you would like to actually add. Would you like to link a credit card, would you like to link a social account? These are all up to you. What's really important about this is that inside of the individual platform, you can actually turn on and off at any time that you like, whichever piece of data you would no longer wish to share. Also important to note is that when somebody purchases this data, i.e. a Procter & Gamble, you have a full transparent record of actually whose purchase is paid at. Similar to a banking record where you would log into your Wells Fargo account, and you would see that you spent $5 at Starbucks, you can log into your Killi account and see that Procter & Gamble has bought your location data and you now have $1 sitting in your account. This is important, too, because we pay you in cash. We are not paying you in crypto, we are not paying you in coupons. We are not paying you in offers, and we're not paying you in points. We're paying you in cash because that is actually how data transacts in the real world. And as I mentioned before, this notion of actually redistributing the wealth or the cash back to the consumers away from the opaque market is really kind of where our kind of core intention is.

What we've also done is we've begun to institute passive revenue opportunities for individual consumers. So we've trademarked such statements as the date dividend or the concept of Fair-Trade Data. These are situations where, should you decide to share location data, you don't have to interact with the application. It's similar to a hydrometer, you would basically pay as you go. So once somebody uses your data, you would get a notification and money would be passively deposited directly into your account.

So let's take a quick look at a few highlights that we've actually focused on over the last 3 months. Then we'll focus on specifically what we're planning on getting to over the remainder of this quarter and then a few additional catalysts specifically for what we -- for the stock. So in Q2, the focus has really been on the addition of new revenue models for the individual consumers. So we've integrated 3 international research companies into the product. This is important because no matter where the product is launched and the product is currently available in half a dozen countries today: U.S., Canada, Australia, Singapore, and New Zealand, with further global expansion planned, is that no matter where you are in the product, there's always an unlimited opportunity for you to actually earn money for answering questions specifically from research firms. We call this active revenue because you actually have to actively participate in a question that someone is working with you, is asking you.

We've also introduced this concept of passive revenue. Passive revenue is where you decide to share a specific piece of data and you're compensated passively when that data is actually used. So we've integrated over 20,000 financial firms into the product today. That allows you to link any card from, say, a Wells Fargo, a TD Bank, a Bank of America. And should a hedge fund that in New York decided that they would like to actually purchase this shopping behavior to see which retail stores are actually having trouble during COVID, you would be passively compensated for that. It will be deposited directly into your account and then you could cash out.

In addition to this, Killi was actually integrated in another company of mine. So on the serial launch of (inaudible), we sold Freckle at the beginning of this year, which put $4 million of cash into the business as well. That's on a draw, it's not $4 million upfront. And then lastly, we've introduced this concept of Fair-Trade Data, which allows consumers to be compensated when advertisers use that data to specifically buy and sell media.

So I'm going to focus specifically here on the credit card module and then a little bit on the audience Fair-Trade Data because I think those are the 2 real levers from Q2 that are really important. As I mentioned, Visa, American Express, Mastercard, any of these various different types of card from any of the 20,000 financial institutions can be linked to our card. Some of you might be familiar with other publicly traded companies like Cardlytics, et cetera. Cardlytics really would take data from Bank of America user and amalgamate it and then provide it to the market. We think that we're the antithesis of that. We're actually -- if you're not buying it from Bank of America, you're actually buying it from the individual consumer. So we believe that this is even more compliant. But the ability to actually link these cards gives up to 2 years' worth of actual shopping data, which again, brands, agencies, hedge funds, et cetera, are very much interested in.

From a revenue model perspective, what's important is that there's a 50-50 rev share between ourselves and the individual clients. So if $1 was being paid to a user, we would get $1. If it was $0.50 being paid to a user, we would get $0.50. So the more data that is actually purchased, the more data we actually make.

Which kind of brings us quickly to this idea of Fair-Trade Data. So this was covered in Forbes Magazine. I would encourage you to read the article on this. And I think this is probably one of the big differentiators that we have in the market. One of the misconceptions that people have is that people buy advertising. Nobody buys advertising. You buy data and then the data manifests into the shape of an advertisement. What that means is that if you were Procter & Gamble and you were looking for a 25- to 54-year old female grocery shopper, you buy that data and then you put a Tide ad on top of it. So all of this data sits inside of these large data management platforms. The big ones are Oracle, LiveRamp, Adobe, Salesforce, et cetera. A lot of this data is unconsented or is referred to as third party. For us, in our past experience, we have integrations with all of these individual platforms to put our Killi data, which is an amalgamation of all of the Killi data into these platforms. So now when you're actually buying a 24-year-old team of grocery shopper, rather than that money going back to the third-party who put the data into Oracle, what we do is we provide a fractional dividend back to every single consumer that actually participated in this.

So what's important about this is that really every major brand and agency uses these data management firms as their watering hole. This is where they go to buy all the data to power all of their media. We are the only company in the world that is offering audience-targeting segments inside of these platforms that actually reward the consumer. Hence the reason we call it Fair-Trade because you, as the consumer can see who's buying the data and you as the buyer of the data can all -- see all the way through to the other side to see who's actually consented to the data.

So the last thing I'll say on this before I move on is that in order to sell data, it's not trivial. We don't just get out of bed and get integrations into platforms like Oracle or Google, et cetera. You have to know your way around it. I mean I've been selling data for the last 20 years. And for me, the key is, is that if you want to sell data, you have to have scale of users, and I'll talk to that in the next slide. You have to have ubiquitous distribution, meaning you need to be in all those places where everybody buys data and then you ultimately have to have demand. At Killi, we have all these 3. So we're integrated into all the major platforms. We have buy-in relationships with all the major agencies and brands. And then we also have all the distribution as well.

So that brings us to Q3 and what we've been working on specifically in Q3. So we'll work back to front here. A global agreement of a top 4 agency holdco. We're hoping to announce that this quarter, where they are using our data to power all of their media. This is a deal that we've already been working on. And we're already -- this company is actually already buying the data. We just have not announced it.

Additionally, constantly focusing on security. The more modules that we put into the product, security is an always-on, never-ending task for us and making sure that when people are adding credit card data or adding driver's license scans that we are making sure that we are at top from a security perspective.

I talked about the audience dividend. We believe that this is going to start to manifest in real revenue this quarter. But the 2 pieces that we are actually introducing this quarter is the browser extension to sit on top of the Google Chrome browser as well as the Killi Elite subscription.

So let me talk to the browser extension, first and foremost. So for context, most of you are familiar with the Google Chrome extension. That's the icon, that's on the left-hand side here. Chrome and its sisters, Edge, Opera and Brave. Those are the browsers to the right of it. They own about 80-plus percent of the browser market. So some of you might think because you have an iPhone that you have Safari, that, that is a powerful browser. The reality is that has basically 3% of the total market. So if you want to do something in the browser space, you have to do something with Chrome. Ultimately for us, we believe the browser is one of the biggest pools of data that is actually leaking personal data directly, specifically actually into Google. So what we know specifically about Google is that they are perpetually collecting all this information. And in fact, there's actually a $5 billion class action lawsuit that Killi was referenced in that -- as a positive example of a company that's actually the antithesis of Google and is providing consumers with actual control of their data. So as I mentioned, 75% to 80% of the global market is in the Chrome market. What we're doing with the browser extension is we're allowing consumers to put all of their browsing data underneath their control for actual sale. What we're also doing is that we will put -- we will give the consumers the opportunity to put an ad blocker on the front end of that browser extension. Why that's important is that this is also a growing trend, 1-in-4, 1-in-5 individual users on the Internet are currently using an ad blocker, but there's not one company in the world that's actually paying people to block ads. We plan on doing that as part of our overall subscription model, which brings us next to Killi Elite, which is the subscription piece of the equation.

So what we found with Killi Elite, and this is kind of runs in parallel with what former Presidential candidate, Andrew Yang, was talking about when he mentioned universal basic income is that, when you sign up to Killi, to simplify the process is that if you would like to make $1, $2 or $5, you can sign up for a subscription. The subscription is pretty simple. It depends on how much data you're willing to share. The more data you're willing to share, the more money you can actually make. So there's not a company in the world currently that is actually providing a subscription model for consumers to be compensated for the data usage. So we think that the combination of a browser extension, ad blocker that actually pays user, plus an overarching subscription model, specifically for consumers, are 2 very, very differentiated products that you're going to see literally in the next 6 to 8 weeks. And these, we believe, are actually going to be very beneficial for us in creating stickiness amongst the individual clients. We think that just the subscription model itself is going to increase the lifetime value of our users by 3x.

So I think whenever we talk about Killi, there's always sort of 2 skeptical questions. The first is great, great idea. Ultimately, we believe in this idea that you should get compensated for your data, you'll find very few people who actually disagree with that sort of thesis. The question always becomes, how are you going to scale it, Neil? Or more specifically, how much money can I make? So the question around how much money you can make, it ranges depending upon how much money -- how many pieces of data you're willing to share, but it ranges anywhere from a $1 at the base level to upwards to over $5. And as we add increasingly more modules, that dollar figure will continue to grow, which will increasingly keep people inside of the product.

But on the scale side, there's really 3 buckets of scale. There is the paid concept, which is that you go to Google or Twitter and you actually buy a user. That's called a cost per acquisition and it's quite dominant amongst most direct-to-consumer kind of companies. There's the organic pillar where you create content, post it on places like Tik Tok, Instagram, that is also quite common. And then there's the partnership component. And so what's important is that we've been doing paid and we've been doing organic, but now we've done the partnership piece. And as a byproduct of us having built the consent framework that allows consumers to opt in and opt out of various pieces of data, what has happened is that companies that have an enormous amount of data that actually are headless, meaning that they have no consumer interaction or they don't have any direct communication with the consumer, have come to us to basically be that consent-as-a-service product, where we are now actually communicating with the consumer on their behalf, allowing them to opt in and opt out. The end result of that is that over the next 2 months, we'll be onboarding over 100 million accounts, specifically in the United States. So the question is always like, how do you get 100 million accounts? As mentioned, we are actually providing the consent framework specifically for companies that actually don't have it. So that's the IP of our business is being able to do that. And just to manage, again, your expectations, you also don't get out of bed, flick the switch and just have 100 million accounts. The goal is to add 50 million of these accounts in August and then 50 million of these accounts in September. We feel confident that we'll be able to add similar types of numbers going into Q4. But this is giving us an enormous amount of scale, which is sort of solidifying the idea that we are the market leader specifically in the space.

So with that in mind, from a cost per acquisition point of view, meaning, how are you actually getting people into your base. The cost per acquisition for us is actually crashing. Whereas in the past, we would have had to actually pay for a user to come in at that $2. Now companies are coming to us and actually paying us to actually work with them specifically on this. And so the cost per acquisition from a model perspective is actually shrinking, whereas the average revenue per user is actually growing. And the average revenue per user, as sort of presented here on the purple side of this circle, is all of those additional modules that we put in.

In short, nothing bad happens when you give more money to consumers. The more money you give to a consumer, the less likely they are to leave the product. The more money you give to a consumer, the longer they'll stay in the product. So if you're thinking about the bottom component of this, which is lifetime value, if you want to increase the lifetime value of the consumer, the fastest way to do that is actually pay people more money.

So we are laser-focused really on how are we actually redistributing more and more wealth to these individual consumers by actually bringing on more and more different modules. So that ties back to the browser extension, subscription, et cetera. These are all things which are going to increase average revenue per user, which will increase lifetime value. That, in combination with kind of a reduced cost per acquisition, creates the unit economics of this model, which actually put us in a situation where we believe that, by the end of this quarter, we're going to be in a cash flow-positive position.

And as you can see from this slide, sort of that very faint pink slide -- that pink images, that is the crashing of our cost per acquisition, which is really in green, kind of our unit economics. The bar graph that is represented here is the dollar value that you can actually get from each of the individual modules. And so when you put 100 million people on top of this pre-existing module -- this pre-existing business model with more and more modules, you'll generate more and more revenue. So the best way to think about this is that the more people you get, the more data you get. The more data you get, the more brands you get. The more brands you get, the more money you get and around and around you go. So we are looking to push towards this revenue flywheel. What we feel that we have is that we feel that we've got the hardest part done, and that is getting the actual individual scale.

So what this looks like from an average revenue per user kind of goals by the data dividend point of view, this sort of outlines for you what some of these things look like. So you can answer surveys, you can do -- you can opt in to location, you can watch videos, you can participate in the audience dividend that I may reference to, you can link a credit card. All of these things are different ways in which you can actually make more money. For us, as an individual company, we participate in every single one of these modules. So when you, as a consumer, link a credit card and that credit card gets sold, you get paid, we get paid. So again, we are incented to have more users sharing increasingly more and more data.

So just to kind of quickly sort of summarize here is that as mentioned, we believe that this concept of data privacy and consumer control of data is a larger trend that is clearly not going away anytime soon. We think that it's looking at kind of the market leaders around the world. We feel that we're at that table. I think you're going to be hard-pressed to find public companies that are operating at this scale with this kind of focus specifically on this market. The Data Privacy regulatory market is global. This is not just U.S., this is in Europe, this is in Canada, this is in United States. Every country in the world is implementing new data privacy policy, which is creating an opportunity for us, as a company, to continue to expand our scale.

Talking specifically about the scale, as I mentioned, adding 100 million accounts in Q3, with similar growth in Q4, we think, kind of allows us to kind of run away with the market. This is a global trend. While we're in half a dozen countries now, we plan on continuing to expand further and further. That revenue flywheel that I made reference to is quite simple in nature, is that, if you're looking at those 3 unit economics: average revenue per user, cost per acquisition and lifetime value, and you're squeezing those to get to a neutral module -- neutral level, as soon as you can get to cash flow positive, then the revenue compounds quite quickly.

And then lastly, the momentum is that we believe that we're the market leader in the space. So with that in mind, I'll kind of quickly answer a few Q&A questions if anybody has them.

Questions and Answers

NEIL SWEENEY: There's a question here specifically around what makes your company unique from your competition, in particular, BIGtoken.

So I would say that big token is schizophrenic. One, they're an investor relations firm. They are sometimes identity firm. They're sometimes a crypto firm. They're sometimes a social firm. We're none of those things. We're focused entirely on identity. So I think that's probably the biggest difference between us. I think that there's also some other things trying to get money out of BIGtoken. They have minimum $20 redemptions for consumers, which we think is unfair. It's also -- we don't think it's transparent. Whereas for us, you can redeem at $5. BIGtoken also doesn't do anything from an audience perspective. It also doesn't do anything from a passive perspective. So we actually don't think the BIGtoken as competition. Any other questions? Okay, great. Thanks so much.

OPERATOR: Thank you. This concludes today's webinar. You may disconnect at this time, and have a great day.

urn:contentItem:5FF9-GV41-JB20-G4GV-00000-00Kilroy Realty Corp at Citi Global Property CEO Conference - Final2015-03-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:06:21ZLexisNexis030215a5628341.741Kilroy Realty Corpat CitiGlobal Property CEO Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* John Kilroy

Kilroy Realty Corporation- Chairman of the Board, President & CEO

* Tyler Rose

Kilroy Realty Corporation- EVP & CFO

Presentation

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Welcome to 03:35 PM session at Citi's 2015 Global Property CEO Conference. This session is for investing clients only and if media or other individuals on the line, please disconnect now. Disclosures are available here and on the webcast on the disclosures tab. We're pleased to have with us Kilroy Realty and CEO John Kilroy. John, I'll turn over to you to introduce your management team and provide a couple minutes of opening remarks and then we'll go to Q&A.

JOHN KILROY, CHAIRMAN OF THE BOARD, PRESIDENT & CEO, KILROY REALTY CORPORATION: Great. Okay. Well, thank you for having us. To my right is Tyler Rose, our CFO, who I think most of you know, and David Simon was here a moment ago, our guide David Simon and how do want to start this? Do you want to just ask questions or you want me to say something?

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: I can ask question and (multiple speakers).

JOHN KILROY: Perfect. Let's go.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: So the first question we're asking everyone. You have 60 seconds to pitch Kilroy stock to new investor and why they should own it over others in the office sector, and now we're going to time you. So, you've 60 seconds.

JOHN KILROY: Okay, real quickly. Kilroy saw earlier than everybody else where office space was going and it's really gone through a transformation. It's gone through a total transformation. A lot of office space you see in the country is now obsolete or becoming obsolete. What we did is to reposition our portfolio and the geography in which we operate. So we're big in Seattle in South Lake Union and Bellevue, which are big tech clusters. We're very big in the San Francisco market, in Silicon Valley markets and down in West Los Angeles, Hollywood -- Hollywood is a very much emerging area, and of course in San Diego. So what we've done is we've sold product that doesn't comport to the future where tenants are going. We positioned ourselves with the assets we bought next to public transportation, all the amenities that the modern workforce wants, and we're building best-in-class assets that are exactly the kind of properties that the most in-demand tenants want. We're doing Dropbox's headquarters, Salesforce's headquarters. We're doing -- we just finished Synopsys' headquarters, big thing for Apple and LinkedIn, DIRECTV's world headquarters, Viacom's new West Coast headquarters. All these assets are producing somewhere between 7.75% to north of that in initial returns for best in product market assets. So think about that compared to buying assets of 3% and 4% that are older and are going to face a lot of CapEx. That's our formula.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: When you sit down as a management team and you talk about those trends, you say: Hey, look, we're leasing to all these tech companies. They're getting brand new office space. They're paying up for it. They're growing really quickly. Are those all positive trends when you sit down sort of behind closed doors or do you worry about some of those?

JOHN KILROY: I worry about everything all the time. I think David Lee said it best, you worry when the market is not great. When the market is fantastic, you worry more because you're wondering whether you're going to miss the inflection point to minimize risk. We minimize risk as follows. We do tremendous preleasing. We just delivered $540 million that's 100% leased. We have $1 billion underway that's 83% leased in the office. There's a component of resi that you don't lease till the end. So, traditionally we've been about 60% preleased. But in this cycle, we've been over 90%. We're going to continue with very high preleasing. And the other way we mitigate risk is we operate with about 28% leverage, and everything we underwrite is to roughly 28% to 30% leverage. So we're not going to get over our skis on debt. In terms of the types of tenants, less than 9% of our tenant base are start-ups. So we're dealing generally with companies with real balance sheets, with real income that have real demand and they're not over leasing space. And then if you look at the markets we're in, all of those markets are the most high demand markets where companies want to grow, whether they're tech, whether they're media or whether they're the fire category. So we're feeling pretty strong right now with what we're seeing in the marketplace, but there will come a time when it's not appropriate to build, where it's not appropriate to buy. That time of buying right now acquisitions I think is more upon us than most people think because what we're seeing now is people buying assets that are not going to serve them well over a long period of time at high price per square foot, which require substantial increases in market rents to make them work. So I think the risk is more on what you buy and how you execute than some of the questions you just asked about, is the tech -- the inputs I got is, is tech going to go away. Everything goes away over time or at least it diminishes. The key is to be well leased and long-term leases and we favor long-term leases.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: You made a comment about companies that aren't overleasing space. How do you measure that?

JOHN KILROY: Well, if you look back to 2000 roughly, companies were overleasing space 20% to 30%. Today, they are over leasing space by about under 5%. So the statistics we look that are helpful, that are by no means all encompassing. We see activity is strongest in our markets and yet it is 50% less than it was in 2000. IPO activity is about 50% less. We see activity is really about 50% less and the shadow space that people are leasing is far less. There is much greater discipline than I've ever seen in my career in terms of companies that are growing so quickly in the way they're managing their balance sheet, in the way they're taking down space. So I think those are all really good trends, but at the end of the day, there is nothing like having leases that are staggered over time and if you're developing having pre-leasing in your pocket, because that's really how you mitigate risk and I think maximize returns over time.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: How do you think about, specifically for San Francisco Prop M, do you think it was a positive or negative for you?

JOHN KILROY: It's funny. Prop M was something that was created 20 years ago and for those who don't know, that pours just under 900,000 square feet of entitlements and do think of a jug, pours in, in every year and if it's not being used, then it accumulates and so there is only about 3 million square feet in that jug right now. And over time, as people develop space, they're going to be in a queue. It's not a queue like a baker's queue. If you're number four at Starbucks, you wait for the other three people in front of you. This is -- some people call it beauty contest. It's what the city feels is going to be in the best interest, whether it's funding their infrastructure or whether it's because you're preserving a certain operation that's been historically part of the fabric of the city. So, in Prop M, you want to make sure where you are in the queue and we feel very strong that we're going to do $450 million project called the Exchange on 16th at Mission Bay. We have a letter of intent on roughly 300,000 square feet of that long-term credit lease. We're in negotiations with other very high credit companies on that. It's one of the few spaces that can be built right now that is in a location that people want.

In terms of future development, we have assembled a little over five acres. It's called a Flower Mart between Fifth and Sixth Street on Brannan. It's probably as best we can tell two years from being entitled it's going to jump a lot of sites that are not as important. We're maintaining the Flower Mart on the property, we'd taken off temporarily and then we put it back, that's a 110 year institution of the city. Very important to keep all those flower growers and sellers in the marketplace. We think that positions us very well vis-a-vis other sites that are going to be looking for entitlements and I can tell you that in terms of dollars per square foot FAR cost, we're going to be somewhere between $50 and $70 in FAR foot cost for that project in a market in which unentitled properties that's behind us is trading for $180 to $200 plus per FAR foot cost and our entitled property is trading for $270 to $300 an FAR foot, if it's entitled.

So what I think is very important and what we tried to do in our Company is when you have entitlement risk, meaning the duration it takes to get entitlement is to make sure you're in at a basis that you can afford at the time that it may take to receive those entitlements and still be able to make money. So we see Prop M as I don't like it from a policy standpoint, but it's a reality and as long as it's a reality, you have to live with it and you need to be very careful in what you're buying locationally and at what price to make sure you can make money when you finally get to develop it and I think there are some others that are making some calculations that are more optimistic than us.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: There's been some stuff in the press on the community not wanting to do anything at the FAR as such, believe it as those don't touch it. It's been [their front] for 10 years, itâ€™s good enough. Does that hurt your ability to get entitlements or you think you're just going to work past that?

JOHN KILROY: Does that hurt our ability to what?

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: To get entitlements or you're just going to work (multiple speakers)?

JOHN KILROY: Well, you know, California is a tough place to get entitlements, right. If anybody for $38 can file a sequel lawsuit once you've received the City Council permission or whatever required. There are activists in the city and many of them have a valid point that they want to see the Flower Mart continue to operate in the city. When we were in escrow to buy these properties and we couldn't address the activists' concerns because we are basically doing two M&A transactions and then we had all kinds of SEC and other regulations that we have comport with. Since that time, we've made it clear that we've entered into a 25-year leased with the Flower Mart. It's our intent and desire and we will keep them there for the long term on a very favorable basis to them. So I'm very optimistic that working with the activists and others that we will be able to get this property entitled to the betterment of the city, and to the betterment of the flower growers and so forth and the residents and to our shareholders.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Questions from the room.

Questions and Answers

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Can you give us an update on what's going on at One Paseo?

JOHN KILROY: One Paseo, that's a project that's mixed use, that we bought the land probably 6.5 years ago to [go turn on] round numbers. It's 23 acres, it was owned for 500,000 square feet of office which would work with surface parking and so forth that we wanted to do something that was more in keeping with the modern workforce. So we worked with the city and we worked with various residents and so forth to come up with a mixed-use project and we received entitlement, rather approval of our entitlements from the City Council a week ago today. And that was a long sojourn I give credit to I think Jed Reagan and his Green Street who came up with the term entitlement purgatory, that's where we were but it's been worth it. And this is what we're going to be able to build. Two, nine story office buildings that are about 480,000 square feet in round numbers, 275,000 square feet of retail, most of which we have leased and three phases of apartments, which total about 608 units. So the estimated cost at round numbers is about $750 million, that's about $610 million or so of new spend. We think we produced a very nice attractive return with that on a property that is going to be, I think the best project mixed-use project in San Diego, certainly one of the best on the West Coast. We're very excited about it, it's a market which has -- needs more apartments, needs more retail and the office space numbers now work which is good because through this uplifting over the last four years, we now see San Diego have a [duress] of Class A space and Del Mar is the most desirable market in San Diego. Now I want to caution everybody that while we can all wait pom-poms for those of us who have been waiting for this to happen, there is a sequel, which is the California Environmental Quality Act and anybody for $38 can file a lawsuit against you and then you have to defend your project because they actually file the lawsuit against the city and then it's based upon a review of your environmental (inaudible) report, did you properly consider everything and so forth. We've had four different major law firms' peer review and they think we're in a really good shape, but it remains to be seen, but we still have a few pom-poms in the air because this has been a long process. Now we go through (inaudible) and then we hopefully can start construction within a year.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: How long until we know if those lawsuits were filed and settled?

JOHN KILROY: Your guess is as good as mine, but I would think -- I don't know what's the statutory, I think they have 45 days, but don't hold me to that. I'm not a lawyer and I haven't been through many secret channels, but I'm sure somebody will file and just because there's a shopping center guy -- anybody from JP Morgan here, I need to talk to you afterwards because you're partner is the guy who has funded all the bad guys. But there is a guy across the street that -- he has to publicly disclose, so he's spent -- I think it was $1.5 million or near about in the fourth quarter being the fly in the ointment. He wants say an exclusive, and he is not going to get one.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Are you going to do the apartments yourself or are you going to partner that out?

JOHN KILROY: We get this question a lot. And just to put in perspective apartments, Dave -- David runs our Southern California operations, and one of the projects we have underway that's very well leased on the office front and he has a big apartment building that comes on stream in early 2016, right? That's about $120 million worth 200 luxury units. In One Paseo, we will have 600 plus units. In the Academy Square project that we will likely start first quarter of next year in Hollywood, we have about 250 units. So, round number is [1,100, 1,200 units] that is a part of next year's projects. Here's the thinking that we had and how we acted on this. We could go out to any number of apartment companies, public or otherwise, and do a venture. And we could do on the retail components go out to any number of retail REITs and do a venture. But first, you've got to get entitled, then you want to get it going. I don't want to spend our brain power doing all these joint ventures that then have to get re-done several times as your entitlements change and so forth, people with different investment horizons, different capital structures, different ownership timeframes. I want to make sure we have projects that work, that can go together, that we can use our energy and talent to get them entitled, get them underway and then we have optionality with regard to those residential units. We can sell them, we can venture them, we can own them. We're not going to become an apartment company. Okay. We're not going to become an apartment company. Whether we'll own some apartments or venture them remains to be seen. But in the context of our shareholders, we believe that the actions we've taken to be able to position ourselves and get these things going were expedited by the direction we went and we have apartment experts and so forth that we fired. And with regard to the exit, if we exit or whether we own, all that is or the most of it is going to accrue to our shareholders as opposed to somebody else. So that's the thinking that's behind it, we made sure we have the capabilities of senior people and construction people and so forth in the enterprise in our Company to execute on this and it's going really well. And in the meantime, the cap rates that we underwrote the Hollywood project Columbia Square initially were about 6.5%, mid-6s in market for that product that's trading under four. So we think it's going to be pretty good for our shareholders.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Was there a thinking that they definitely was bringing in sort of a development partner but non-ownership partner, was that different than it would be at One Paseo or is that sort of similar?

TYLER ROSE, EVP & CFO, KILROY REALTY CORPORATION: Well, I'll tell about Hollywood, I mean what we brought in is a highly respected and company that has done apartments, has done hospitality and help us kind of perfect the strategy that we want to do and they have just a management agreement with an incentive. So it's an incentive management agreement. But we got their expertise associated with that and it's all, it's a great relationship. With respect to One Paseo, I think we could do that there as John said, there's any number of apartment guys that approach us in various structures coming in, partnering with us, managing with us and I think we're sorting through all those interview and trying to figure out the best way to execute ultimately what we're doing down there, but we have great product in these locations. We have our choice.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Any questions from the floor.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Hi John, in terms of -- you're in some great markets, all growth markets that I think most of your peers would like to be in. But when you guys said and you look at where do I allocate the next incremental dollar today, is it San Francisco, is it Hollywood, is it Del Mar, is it something, is it Seattle?

JOHN KILROY: Look, San Francisco is, at least on the West Coast, a class by itself. Everybody wants to be in San Francisco, and because of the growth, and this is-- what's happened is this. Think about technology, entertainment and all these different companies what's their most important asset. People, their people cost roughly 80%, real estate costs roughly 5%. You pay 20% more for your real estate but it positively influences the 80% either by attracting, retaining or being more productive, itâ€™s fantastic leverage. We do not get into a long negotiations on rental rates. We do at the [French] but it's not like the old days, it's more like will the facility, does it have the locational characteristics and the amenities and the (inaudible) and so forth that's necessary for us to attract and retain people. So, I'm going to start with the fact that we want to be in those markets that are really going to be terrific markets for the long-term. Whereas to how we allocate the incremental dollar, right now, in San Francisco we have about $1.5 billion between the two projects. About a third of that is the Exchange on 16th, which will start this year. A couple years out San Francisco, I'm not sure how much more Prop M risk we want to take and what we're seeing right now is some of the projects that would be good projects that they were entitled but are going to be later in the queue. I think a lot of those are going to recalibrate and come back to us because we are already having people say, would you recap us or would you venture this with us and so forth. So more to be seen there. In South Lake Union, the property we bought at 333 Dexter, it is 580,000 feet, it is $350 million plus a couple of our parcels. We're negotiating with somebody right now for the entire year that whether we do the deal or not, I don't know. Surprise, surprise, it's a major tech company and down in San Diego, we mentioned that project, more and more of media and so forth in Hollywood. So I'm not going to say that we are going to do more in this market or that market other than what I've said, we're going to be opportunistic, but we are not going to get to a point where we have a lopsided company. Six years ago, we are 100% Southern California and we were 55% San Diego. Today on a pro forma basis, meaning this stuff that we have under development gets completed tighter, what are basically our ratios?

TYLER ROSE: 35% to 40% San Francisco, 15% to 20% Seattle, 25% LA and the remainder [about some 20%] San Diego.

JOHN KILROY: And what I had said year ago when people asked me five years ago how do you see over time the balance of the portfolio, I said it kind of feels right, half is in the southern part of the state and half of it's sort of San Francisco and points north. That's kind of what we've done. San Francisco by -- and by the way, we're talking about percentage, we're talking about NOI, we're not talking about square footage. We are very clued into what major companies are doing, what their expansion plans are, we talk to them all the time about what we're doing and cross marketing, they talk to us about what we are doing and what they're doing. And so the way this plays out over time, I'm not going to be hard and fast and say it's 50% Southern California, 50% points north, but that feels pretty good. I've said San Diego a few years ago, I see kind of if what we have been as square footage now or NOI, not as a percentage, but just absolute amount if that's X, 120% to 80% of X seems about right. I'm sure we'll bounce around maybe a little one side or the other at times.

We're focused more on where we see extraordinary value that can be created and to put a couple of metrics for you into perspective, right now in San Francisco, Class A office space is really well-located. It's going to trade somewhere between 3% and 5% depending upon weather has problems etcetera, etcetera. And it's going to closer to that lower number. It's going to in the threes more than the fives. In San Diego, we're seeing high fours to high fives depending upon whether it's really Class A or whether it's more suburban stuff. We're selling $250 million right now down there. That's going to be in the fives, but it's not stuff that we want to own for long-term but we turnaround and put that stuff into 7.75%, 8% plus brand new state-of-the-art projects that have all the modern features and locationally, in fact, they're where people want to be, we're going to continue to do that trade. So I don't want you to get hung up on percentages here percentages there but it kind of feels right sort of 50% north 50% south, 25%, 20% San Diego. Now all San Diego people who listen to this call are going be upset [at] for me because they're going to interpret that as we're selling off San Diego. We're going to sell some stuff in LA. We have, we're going to sell some stuff in San Francisco at some point, we're going to sell some stuff in Seattle at some point because at the end of the day, we do not have a mother fixation about any particular piece of property. We are in the business to make money on a per share basis. So we look at the denominator when you buy stuff and we look at what where the values over time and if we see substantial increases in value, we're going to keep the asset and if we don't see substantial increases in value or at least not, there is still long before you can uncork it, then we're probably going to sell it at some point. So you'll see us continue to be very active as we've been in the last three years.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: As we sit today, when might some of those sales start to come up?

JOHN KILROY: Well, we have $250 million in San Diego. The smaller buildings, all good buildings. Some of them are worried because the stuff we're selling is better than most of the stuff I see a lot of people buying but we have $250 million in the market in San Diego, right now I think we took best in finals last week or thereabouts. So (inaudible) whether there might be another best and final round. We're selling a $50 million property in Redmond Washington. We recently recapped the lease with Microsoft, it's non-strategic asset, great building. It was the first building we bought up there. That's going to be sold and we've sort of said that this year, we would do sort of $250 million to $400 million worth of sales. Could be quite a bit more than that, I don't know, don't have anything else in the market right now, but we are getting a lot of request to sell some of the big campuses we've done over the last few years at pretty tremendous cap rates. Tremendous means, very low cap rates.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Tyler, how do you think about funding One Paseo, that's $600 million that you have to spend there?

TYLER ROSE: Well, the strategy for funding is going to be the same, it's disposition strategy and unsecured debt strategy and then equity, and we've been doing about a third, a third, a third. We raised $100 million on our ATM in the fourth quarter. We're going to continue to use the ATM as needed. As John said, we have $300 million in the market on dispositions and we have one debt maturity at the end of the year. That's about $325 million. And we will probably raise a little bit more than that at that point. But going forward, on these future development opportunities, it will be the same combination of those three elements to raise the capital. Right now, we have about $500 million of spending this year, which we can cover with, that's ATM and the dispositions.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: John, can you go through the Bay Area sub-markets and where is -- what are the preferred locations? Talk about the (inaudible) or other dynamics and has it changed over the last year or so?

JOHN KILROY: Well, look at the city to begin with, you have Market Street, you have the North Financial, which is the historic Financial District, insurance companies, lawyers, financial institutions and so forth. Market buildings over there, some of them have become more commodity like because they're not close to public transportation. They are not on the south side of market, which has been the high area of demand. By no means am I criticizing people who own facilities on the north side. We've not bought any there, and there is a reason. You don't get quite as high a rent unless you have a really terrific view space and most -- the biggest segment, if you think of a pie of demand, 70 some odd percent don't want to be north of market. So we just look at the math and say: okay, so let's be on the other side where we've been able I think the proof is in the pudding. We started by building at 333 Brannan. Dropbox leased it a week after we started construction. You've seen the pattern time and time again with the buildings we've done over there. The rents that we're able to achieve over there are higher. The terms are better. It's stronger demand if the transportation is better. When the city determined that they were going to build a Transbay Terminal 20 years ago, they knew that the center of the city would shift to the south side of Market Street. That's exactly what's happened. And then you have the Central SoMa Corridor, the subway that will connect BART on market with stops intervening one of blocks in the Flower Mart, then to Caltrain. So BART for those who don't know connect everybody to the East Bay so people go back and forth. Caltrain is the primary way other than automobile that you connect to the South Bay meaning Silicon Valley and down beyond. And then the Central Corridor connects all of that.

So we're very much captive to the notion that the modern workforce needs to be next to public transportation. And if you look at all the statistic kids aren't doing drivers' license, they can -- you can't afford to build a parking -- they won't let you build the parking and with the density, you just got to be there. So that's the city. Moving on down South. On the Peninsula, power vault is fantastic. Again, buildings near power vault. Middle part fantastic, very hard to build there. We own a lot of property there. We are a 100% leased there, you go down to the Sunnyvale. And middle part, by the way is a battleground between LinkedIn and of course the big Google. Everybody is trying to secure their futures. So the property values there have just gone out of whack. It's very hard to buy anything. Sunnyvale is the same thing. Apple has just grown like mad there. LinkedIn grown like mad there, Facebook's expanding like mad. For those of you who follow this a plug from my buddy (inaudible) done in selling property to Facebook and to Google where they bought big swaths of property that's currently industrial to protect their flanks for the future growth and you're just seeing, the closer you are to the city, the more valuable. As you go down to San Jose, don't like that market at all. Nobody seems to want to go there. Santa Clara has done pretty well. Go to the East Bay there is Oakland and you know, we don't spend any time looking at Oakland. Not that Oakland will do well over time, I guess, but we think -- we are very much about office, where you can get things leased and make money, charge higher rents over time and defense where people want to be. I have seen this time and time again where people go to the out fringe because everything internally is all these stuff and the rates are high, then the market reduces in terms of demand and the people that's are on the fringe move back in. I've been doing this longer I think than anybody in this room, I would make that bet, okay. I see some grey hairs. It's nice to see a few people with grey hair, prematurely grey I know. You can't fight reality and reality is that people want to be in the best buildings in the best locations if they can afford it. So you got to think defense for long game, and some of the markets I don't think are defensive by nature, they're opportunistic. So for a trader they might make sense at any given time but we're not traditionally traders.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: For potential joint venture, I'm sure there's lots of sovereign wealth guys that are talking to you guys about doing stuff. If you think about like a single tenant Salesforce tower versus some of the mixed-use stuff you guys are developing currently, would you be more likely to JV a single tenant, long-term lease building like Salesforce, or one of mixed-use projects that you guys are developing either in Hollywood or potentially down in San Diego?

JOHN KILROY: Bill, you're trying to put me on a hot seat. Let's not say Salesforce, let's just say some of the stuff, very well leased single tenant. Those are obvious assets over time to sell and trade into something else or to venture. We have everybody in the world trying to -- I shouldn't say everybody, but quite a few players that are major international, whether they're sovereigns or major pension bonds, they would love to venture with us. Some of the things we've recently completed, some of things that we have underway, both in the north and the south, we look at that. I think most of you know me know that I don't really like partners. I've got a whole bunch of partners I call the public, okay? But they're not trying to tell me every day how to negotiate a deal and spending a long time with lawyers to figure out whether we're on the same page. Having said that, with the exception of CMBS, which we don't do, the one area in our capital stack, if you will, that we don't have is the sovereign and do we do a sovereign or a major pension fund, do we do something on one of our assets in due course? Maybe, but it would be with the thought that they -- you'd have an expanded relationships some time when maybe there is an [interruptance] in the market and there's a great inflection point to be major buyers again, because a lot of the stuff that we bought that we've been given a lot of kudos for during the 2010, 2011, 2012, 2013 cycle I suppose in retrospect, we should have bought twice as much. And if you see that kind of an opportunity again, you want to make sure you have the capital source to do it. So maybe, maybe. Nothing imminent, no negotiations are underway. Every partner I ever had always ended up on a different playbook at the end. They always wanted something different and you weren't in alignment and just was mind boggling. So I have a natural tendency to like simple, so that we're agile, and we are not just didn't meetings to have meeting. But that doesn't mean never.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Any last questions from the room? Alright. we'll switch to the rapid fire, John. What will same-store NOI growth be for the office sector in 2016?

JOHN KILROY: The office sector? I don't know. You guys know that. I don't follow anybody else. We've said, it's somewhere in 2.5% to 3.0% range but we have very little to lease. I will tell you that our mark to market in San Francisco 300,000 feet or so that comes up this year is about, we're about 50% under market. So we like that.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: But throw in a number? [I'll settle for it] now.

JOHN KILROY: 3.5% for the sector.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: For the sector.

JOHN KILROY: Then we better beat them. You want your bonus.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Are cap rates for your assets higher or lower one year from today?

JOHN KILROY: I saw that panel that Michael did and I wrote, I thought they'd be about the same. So I'm kind of guessing that.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Higher or lower?

JOHN KILROY: Higher or lower. (technical difficulty) I think the cap rates are pretty good, we're seeing a lot more pressure in terms of folks that want to buy stuff. So I think they could go lower, but I don't know.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: What inning are we in this real estate cycle?

JOHN KILROY: Depends on the market. I think we're probably in kind of a mid-game in San Diego. We might be an inning or two one way or the other in San Francisco, it is just hard to tell. What I know a fair amount about is where major companies are going and what their plans are for two years and three years out. Whether there's something that come along macro that interrupts their plans, I can't tell you, but it feels pretty strong. I feel for what I'm seeing and hearing with our client base and demand I'm feeling that there is more life left today than I thought there was at this time last year.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: All right, thank you.

JOHN KILROY: You are welcome.

value.Title: Kilroy Realty Corp at Citi Global Property CEO Conference - Final
