urn:contentItem:5W00-88P1-F03R-N48Y-00000-00Kremlin Watch Briefing: What can the West do for Ukraine now?2019-04-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:06:21ZLexisNexisKremlin Watch Briefing: What can the West do for Ukraine now?Ольга Юркова

Apr 26, 2019( StopFake.org: http://stopfake.org/en/ Delivered by Newstex) NEW PUBLICATIONThe European Values Think-Tank introduces a newpublication[1]authored by our Non-resident Fellow Liubov Tsybulska: 'Ukraine beyond 2019: Where should Western democracies assist?'It examines the relevance, lessons learnt and vulnerabilities in the following spheres: Development of society on civic principle instead of ethnic Reintegration of Crimea, Donetsk and Luhansk regions Work with historical memory Psychological support for the most traumatized groups of the population Development of the political and cultural elite of Ukraine Read the full reporthere[2].Topics of the WeekPro-Kremlin disinformers know who caused the Notre Dame's burning. If we want to talk about the big tech companies, we should not forget aboutYouTube. Kremlin rejects the Mueller report, while evidence indicatedRussian oligarchs attempted to meet Trump.

NATO StratCom COE presents30 geopolitical scenarios with a focus on strategic communicationsin its new study.Good Old Soviet JokeA lecturer from the District Party committee says to the workers, 'The imperialists meddle in the internal affairs of the USSR all over the globe.'Policy ...search News Notre Dame burns as disinformation machine engagesAfter surviving two World Wars, the French Revolution and many more political upheavals, the 21stcentury saw the destruction of parts of the approx. 900-year-old structure. But, as the embers were still burning,the Kremlin's disinformation channels began blaming the Yellow Vests, Muslims, and exploiting the tragedy to further divide Western culture[3]. The speed of the reaction and its global reach is noteworthy. In other bizarre arguments, France was now suffering because it had supported hard-line Nazis in Ukraine, bringing the then-candidate Volodymyr Zelensky. Though this attempt may have failed even on RT channels, failure is, as we know, part and parcel of the Russian strategy. No matter how absurd, while this attempt may have fallen flat, the seeds of dishonesty and absurdity are sown.Let's not forget about YouTubeA piece onThe Verge[4]discussed a recentNew York Times profile[5]of the YouTube CEO Susan Wojcicki. In particular, it points out that, while she is sheltered from some of the pressures facing Facebook and Twitter due to corporate structure, she also runs a platform uniquely suited to amplify disinformation, in a way that Facebook is not. According to The Verge, the two simply have different usages - Fakebook's primary function of facilitating connections means it is better positioned to filter out unwanted or polarising content. Meanwhile, as an entertainment site, YouTube naturally tilts towards the sort of content that will generate more attention and thus, more ad revenue. More specifically, it relies heavily on the so-called 'borderline content' - videos coming close to violating YouTube's content regulations without crossing that thin line. This is a problem that's built into the platform, as 'borderline content' creates the most engagement on the site. It is clear both YouTube generally and Susan Wojcicki specifically faces a serious problem, and the pressure is mounting for it to adjust its algorithms in order to reduce exposure and distribution of false or otherwise 'borderline' content. However, it remains to be seen whether the company will make good on its promises to improve, and how it will do it without jeopardising its business in the process.Ukrainian election as a testing groundAfter Ukraine published an expansive White Book this winter, its exemplary place as a testing ground for Russian hybrid and disinformation campaigns has held its ground. As it is a testing ground for the Kremlin, its defensive tactics can prove as progressive as the attacks themselves.The Atlantic sat down with Dmytro Zolotukhin, the man in charge of Ukraine's information policy[6]. The Ministry of Information Policy was only founded in 2016 but continues to be woefully underfunded. Though Ukraine has taken hard-line tactics to ban Russian social-media alternatives and even search engines, this has of course simply called for more ingenious attacks. Kyiv is becoming the vanguard site for the global problem governments face: do they restrict free speech in the face of foreign threats, and consider the restrictions they place on the rights that come with a free democracy? Ukraine is looking to ban outlets that spread disinformation only during elections times, and education programs have also help promising results.'The Europeans' discuss national differences in misinformationOn this week's'The Europeans' podcast[7], the hostKaty Lee[8](Agence France - Presse) talks with Jules Darmanin, who leads a new cross-border initiative of journalist fact-checkers calledFactCheckEU[9]. The organization translates debunks among European languages, as well as fosters cross-border investigative projects and answers general questions about European policies and the news. Darmanin explains the rationale for creating an international fact-check organization, which is that disinformation has no borders. A famous example is a Greek TV presenter stating that refugees in Germany had been receiving 'brothel vouchers' - a rumour which originated in Austria and Germany. In general, disinformation about migrants and refugees is among the most mobile due to its global and polarising nature. According to him, it is hard to say whether some countries are more susceptible to misinformation than others. However, in some cases it appears to spread and take root easier. Greece is one such case, where after a prolonged economic crisis legacy news outlet are understaffed and that vacuum has allowed for more provocative media outlets to foster. In other cases, such as in the so-called 'news deserts' without local news outlets in the US, which allows lower quality outlets to monopolize the information space.US Developments Kremlin's response to the Mueller reportWhile the Mueller Report established there was not a collision between Trump and the Kremlin during the 2016 election cycle, a redacted version of the report released last Thursday includes detailed information about the efforts by the Russian intelligence services to hack servers at the Democratic National Committee, certain Russian businessman attempting to forge ties with Trump, and a disinformation campaign waged by the Internet Research Agency to influence American voters in 2016. However,Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov[10]said that the report 'still does not present any conclusive evidence of alleged interference by the Russian Federation in the electoral process in America and we continue to refuse to accept any such accusation.' Three Russian businessmen: Petr Aven, Kirill Dmitriev, and Sergey Gorkov, who all have close ties to Vladimir Putin, attempted to reach out to Trump or his administration in 2016[11]. The Mueller report revealed that Petr Aven attempted to reach out to the Presidential Transition Team in connection to anticipated post-election sanctions. Aven told investigators that he met regularly with Putin in 2016, and he said that Putin's suggestions during these meetings wereunderstood to be 'directives'[12], which entailed consequences for not following through. Kiril Dmitriev who also attempted to make contact with the Trump transition team is noteworthy for drafting a plan for U.S. Russia reconciliation with Rick Gerson a close friend of Jared Kushner and calling Putin his 'boss'. Sergey Gorkov, who served as a senior manager for Sberbank,met with Jared Kushner[13]on December 13, 2016. The Mueller report detailed that Gorkov gave Kushner a painting and a bag of soil from the town in Belarus that his family originally hailed from, however, the report did not establish any conclusions on the nature of the meeting. While Gorkov said the meeting was strictly business related, the fact he brought Kushner gifts makes it questionable.China and Russia seek influence in Latin AmericaOver recent months the U.S. has beenstruggling to develop ways to prevent[14]China and Russia from furthering their influence in Latin America, and this is occurring amidst Latin American governments seeking to distance themselves from the Trump administration. In the past, U.S. defence officials have sought non-force option such as humanitarian missions and more training for Latin American armed forces todeter China and Russia in Venezuela[15]and Latin America as a whole, however, Trump recent bids to curb Latin American migration and drug trafficking to the U.S., have come at a cost. Due to the rush of migrants at the U.S. border, the Trump administration has plans toslash aid[16]for Honduras, El Salvador, and Guatemala because the administration does not view the aid as being effective. Trump has alsoplaced sanctions[17]on Cuba and Nicaragua for their support of the Maduro government in Venezuela andrecalled diplomats[18]after Central American nations stopped recognizing Taiwan. This is leading Latin American officials to reassess the worth of U.S. relationships andBenjamin Gedan[19]a former National Security Council official said this is 'Entirely Counterproductive..The Trump administration's policies have supercharged China's increased presence in the region.' Both China and Russia have invested billions in Venezuela, and Russian has not shown hesitation to antagonize the U.S. in the nation and demonstrate its might. While China has been increasing its presence heavily in the region and is attempting to replace American influence in disgruntled countries, Russia's presence has been mainly confined to Venezuela.R. Evan Ellis[20]a research professor at the U.S. Army War College has said that Russian proliferation of arms and military hardware has declined as nations look to China for more reliable systems. Russia's strategy in the region also seems to point more towards provocation than strategy—unlike China. Ellis described the Russian presence as showing more weakness than strength and not having any long term sustainability.Kremlin Watch Reading Suggestion Hybrid Threats: A Strategic Communications PerspectiveThis week, we recommend a newstudy[21]by the NATO StratCom COE, which is designed to help national authorities buildresilience to hybrid threatsand effectively respond to them. It presents30 detailed case studieswith a broad variety of geopolitical scenarios (from Russian snap exercises in the High North to Pakistani involvement in Yemen) and focuses on Strategic Communications. Defining hybrid threats as a 'type of threat that combines conventional, irregular and asymmetric activities in time and space', it emphasises that their key aspect is ambiguity - that is, the responsible actors and overall intent are often unclear. Therefore, understanding the hybrid threat environment requires an appreciation of the interplay between information, perception, interpretation, and decision-making.Strategic Communicationswith its holistic approach based on values and interests should be endorsed as a guiding principle across all levels of government with a recognition that communication is not limited to words but can encompass any action or inaction. Furthermore, it is necessary to evaluate the underlying thinking and aims behind adversarial actions as well as to identify a country's own existing vulnerabilities (such as domestic issues), which malign actors may seek to exploit. Although not every action is a threat, it is important for government departments to be proactive and have an understanding of the information environment. Meanwhile,setting clear objectives consistent with core values, in addition to coherent and factual government communications will help preserve credibility. Kremlin Watchis a strategic program of the European Values Think-Tank, which aims to expose and confront instruments of Russian influence and disinformation operations focused against liberal-democratic system. urn:contentItem:5PN1-RNR1-JBH0-M0NB-00000-00Křetínský: Vychováváme naprosté politické ignoranty. Musíme podpořit kvalitní média, která jsou pilířem demokracie2018-10-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:06:21ZLexisNexisPg. 0Křetínský: Vychováváme naprosté politické ignoranty. Musíme podpořit kvalitní média, která jsou pilířem demokracieOndřej Houska

Od našeho zvláštního zpravodaje - Miliardář Daniel Křetínský tvrdě zkritizoval digitální giganty, jako jsou Google, nebo Facebook. "Nikdy v historii neměla žádná firma ani zdaleka takovou moc, jakou mají tyto společnosti," prohlásil majitel Energetického a průmyslového holdingu nebo fotbalové Sparty s tím, že to platí hlavně o Googlu. Podle Křetínského je potřeba přijmout nová pravidla, která by internetové firmy regulovala. "Potřebujeme úplně novou regulaci, uvedl Křetínský na konferenci Globsec Tatra Summit na Štrbském Plese na Slovensku. Podnikatel si myslí, že Google či Facebook možná budou muset po přijetí nové regulace část svých aktivit prodat. Dominance Googlu či Facebooku má podle Křetínského negativní důsledky i pro média, a tím pro celou společnost. Upozornil na skutečnost, že tyto firmy získávají dominantní podíl z příjmů z reklamy na internetu, i když netvoří žádný vlastní obsah. Tradiční média i kvůli tomu upadají. "Jsem opravdu velký zastáncem tradičních médií a tradiční novinařiny," řekl Křetínský, který do médií sám investuje. "Jsou důležitým pilířem demokracie v Evropě." Pochvala

Evropská komisařka pro hospodářskou soutěž ocenila Křetínského vystoupení na Tatra Summitu Very strong and impressive @DKretinsky advocating for new, strong, stable regulations for big tech *TatraSummit2018 @BrusselsGeek pic.twitter.com/kPQ5E24iYO — Margrethe Vestager (@vestager) October 5, 2018

Fakt, že stále víc občanů čerpá informace jen z internetu, například přes Facebook, má podle Křetínského negativní důsledky pro demokratickou společnost. Zatímco dříve lidem zprostředkovávala informace kvalitní média, dnes "vychováváme generaci naprostých politických ignorantů". Tak Křetínský označil stav, kdy lidé čtou jen titulky, pokud se vůbec na nějaké zpravodajské stránky dívají. Křetínský tímto způsobem odpověděl na otázku HN, proč sám média vlastní. Prohlásil, že tradiční "média jsou, bohužel, tak slabá, že musí být podporována". Zatímco dříve lidé podle něj interpretovali události podle toho, co se dočetli v kvalitních médiích a i na základě toho se rozhodovali ve volbách, dnes se chování občanů změnilo. Křetínský vlastní společnost CNC, což je největší mediální dům v Česku. Patří pod ní například deník Blesk, týdeník Reflex, rádiová stanice Frekvence 1 nebo server Info.cz. Křetínský nedávno nakoupil několik médií ve Francii či Rumunsku. Na konferenci Globsec Tatra Summit dodal, že proti Googlu nebo Facebooku nechce vést žádný boj – vyjádřil obdiv nad tím, jak přispěly k inovacím nebo jak dokážou stále růst, takže si zaslouží být největšími firmami na světě. Zároveň se ale podle něj svět dostal do situace, kdy "tradiční monopoly jsou dětskými hračkami v porovnání s dnešními digitálními monopoly". Křetínský taky upozornil, že Google v Česku na daních zaplatil jen 0,1 procenta z příjmů, kterých v Česku dosáhl.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5PN1-RNR1-JBH0-M156-00000-00Křetínský: Vychováváme naprosté politické ignoranty. Musíme podpořit kvalitní média, která jsou pilířem demokracie2018-10-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:06:21ZLexisNexisPg. 0Křetínský: Vychováváme naprosté politické ignoranty. Musíme podpořit kvalitní média, která jsou pilířem demokracieOndřej Houska

Od našeho zvláštního zpravodaje - Miliardář Daniel Křetínský tvrdě zkritizoval digitální giganty, jako jsou Google, nebo Facebook. "Nikdy v historii neměla žádná firma ani zdaleka takovou moc, jakou mají tyto společnosti," prohlásil majitel Energetického a průmyslového holdingu nebo fotbalové Sparty s tím, že to platí hlavně o Googlu. Podle Křetínského je potřeba přijmout nová pravidla, která by internetové firmy regulovala. "Potřebujeme úplně novou regulaci, uvedl Křetínský na konferenci Globsec Tatra Summit na Štrbském Plese na Slovensku. Podnikatel si myslí, že Google či Facebook možná budou muset po přijetí nové regulace část svých aktivit prodat. Dominance Googlu či Facebooku má podle Křetínského negativní důsledky i pro média, a tím pro celou společnost. Upozornil na skutečnost, že tyto firmy získávají dominantní podíl z příjmů z reklamy na internetu, i když netvoří žádný vlastní obsah. Tradiční média i kvůli tomu upadají. "Jsem opravdu velký zastáncem tradičních médií a tradiční novinařiny," řekl Křetínský, který do médií sám investuje. "Jsou důležitým pilířem demokracie v Evropě." Pochvala

Evropská komisařka pro hospodářskou soutěž ocenila Křetínského vystoupení na Tatra Summitu Very strong and impressive @DKretinsky advocating for new, strong, stable regulations for big tech *TatraSummit2018 @BrusselsGeek pic.twitter.com/kPQ5E24iYO — Margrethe Vestager (@vestager) October 5, 2018

Fakt, že stále víc občanů čerpá informace jen z internetu, například přes Facebook, má podle Křetínského negativní důsledky pro demokratickou společnost. Zatímco dříve lidem zprostředkovávala informace kvalitní média, dnes "vychováváme generaci naprostých politických ignorantů". Tak Křetínský označil stav, kdy lidé čtou jen titulky, pokud se vůbec na nějaké zpravodajské stránky dívají. Křetínský tímto způsobem odpověděl na otázku HN, proč sám média vlastní. Prohlásil, že tradiční "média jsou, bohužel, tak slabá, že musí být podporována". Zatímco dříve lidé podle něj interpretovali události podle toho, co se dočetli v kvalitních médiích a i na základě toho se rozhodovali ve volbách, dnes se chování občanů změnilo. Křetínský vlastní společnost CNC, což je největší mediální dům v Česku. Patří pod ní například deník Blesk, týdeník Reflex, rádiová stanice Frekvence 1 nebo server Info.cz. Křetínský nedávno nakoupil několik médií ve Francii či Rumunsku. Na konferenci Globsec Tatra Summit dodal, že proti Googlu nebo Facebooku nechce vést žádný boj – vyjádřil obdiv nad tím, jak přispěly k inovacím nebo jak dokážou stále růst, takže si zaslouží být největšími firmami na světě. Zároveň se ale podle něj svět dostal do situace, kdy "tradiční monopoly jsou dětskými hračkami v porovnání s dnešními digitálními monopoly". Křetínský taky upozornil, že Google v Česku na daních zaplatil jen 0,1 procenta z příjmů, kterých v Česku dosáhl.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5TM5-V3W1-JDPT-T00D-00000-00KRISTINA HOOPER, CHIEF GLOBAL MARKET STRATEGIST, INVESCO IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG T.V.2018-10-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:06:22ZLexisNexisKRISTINA HOOPER, CHIEF GLOBAL MARKET STRATEGIST, INVESCO IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG T.V.

October 29, 2018

NEWS PROGRAM

KRISTINA HOOPER, CHIEF GLOBAL MARKET STRATEGIST, INVESCO

ABRAMOWICZ: Let's bring in Kristina Hooper, Invesco Global Chief Market Strategist.

Kristina, what you make of today's sell-off and does it give you a sense that we're not done here with the pain?

HOOPER: I haven't expected this to be done and this just confirms that. We've got a lot of trepidations going into midterm elections. And to that, we've had a lot of other unresolved issues, from Brexit to the Italian fiscal situation. We've added some risks in there in terms of Angela Merkel's resignation.

There's a lot going on. And of course a pervasive weight on market is concerns about trade and as well as Fed tightening and neither both have gone away.

WEISENTHAL: Are there any opportunities here that when you look down at all this like sort of wall of worry that you're describing, all these chaos, are there areas that the market that are standing out is like, OK, this is getting a little much.

HOOPER: Absolutely. And the sell-off in tech has been overdone. There's a lot of concern, whispers that if we see a Democratic House there could be greater regulation on tech. And I think that's fueling some of the concerns around tech.

ABRAMOWICZ: And the U.K. budget today that they're going to be taxing some of the big tech companies.

HOOPER: Absolutely. And so that has weighed down on tech but that's where we can get some pretty significant secular growth.

WEISENTHAL: I just think it's worth pointing out, we're not even down that much anymore. We've had a pretty nice bounce, S&P down 0.6%, Dow 1%. Still deeply red but clearly off the worst levels from literally just when I got on.

ABRAMOWICZ: Well, and that's my question, Mike, to you. Are we just seeing Argos going wild?

(BREAK)

HYDE: And, Kristina, you were just saying that you weren't expecting this bouncing off these days anytime, but we do have a divided market voice here at the moment. We have Goldman Sachs saying, hey, stop buying. The valuations got too eroded here. And then we have Morgan Stanley saying, you know, sell every rally. Where do you sit on the spectrum?

HOOPER: I sit in a very neutral place and that I have a long-term time horizon.

HYDE: In Switzerland.

HOOPER: I think you could say. I have a very long-term time horizon and we encourage our investors to have very long time horizons. And in that environment, certainly, there are opportunities to be tactical and pick up some bargains but certainly there's no place for a wholesale removal from this market.

WEISENTHAL: We thought we're going to be talking about the big story of the day which was IBM buying Red Hat. And the sympathy trade with a bunch of tech, all those sort of arrays, but what do you make of like big juicy M&A deals like that people say about the whole space?

(BREAK)

HYDE: Let's get back to Kristina Hooper of Invesco and Bloomberg's Mike Regan.

Kristina, I want to get your sense and perspective on what it means for China for you at the moment because this is what sent off lower was the concern that tariffs could be ramping up once again?

HOOPER: And I think that's absolutely what we still be concerned about. In fact, I would take the news this morning that China was cutting auto taxes is actually a negative 2. Because that's one more stimulative act that they've done from cutting rates to devaluating the yuan to essentially supported economy. That tells me they're hunkering down and getting ready for a full-blown trade war, including the talks they've just had with Japan. This is not intended to be -- they don't expect to capitulate from everything I'm seeing. And so I would expect the trade talk to be unsuccessful next month and for us to go into more full blown trade wars.

WEISENTHAL: Speaking of capitulation when do we start seeing the market or the Fed or the market's perception of the Fed come down with respect to the pace of rate hikes?

HOOPER: Well, we need to hear some messaging from the Fed because keep in mind, last week, we continued to hear full speed ahead. Although the Loretta Mester did give us a bit of an out and said, well, essentially we're still data dependent so we could change course.

So I think we need to listen to messaging from the Fed and also of course follow the economic data. For example the jobs report this week. If we have an easing in wage growth it remains very modest, then that gives the Fed a bit more flexibility to take its foot off the accelerator.

ABRAMOWICZ: You know, I have to wonder too, Joe's point though, about interest rates. Interestingly, on this risk off day, yet again, we see 10-year yields and the two-year yields and the day slighter higher which indicates that we are not going to the haven type of asset class and should be somewhat unnerving. And I have to wonder, you know, Caroline, you point to the trade tensions, but how much of this really underneath is a rate-hiking story. And I wonder what you're hearing, Mike, from your sources.

(BREAK)

ABRAMOWICZ: Hold on one second. Kristina, do you buy this? Do you buy that this is just like rebalancing issue or do you think this is real sort of higher rates.

HOOPER: I do think this is a higher rate issue. Although it is combined with a trade issue because trade is finally getting tangible. So really it's in Switzerland.

HYDE: Oh, Kristina, what about the dollar? How much of this is a concerned about the dollar story we're hearing in earnings now, how much and what's falling on the back that we worried about dollar strength?

HOOPER: Well, the dollar is so interrelated with the Fed story, right? Because the closest correlation with the dollar going higher is expectations about Fed's fund rate. So it's all interconnected. And certainly trade has played a role in boosting the dollar as well.

WEISENTHAL: OK. So what's going to turn the market around? What is the market looking for? Earnings, it doesn't really seem to be doing it. Do you think the trade war is going it get worse? It doesn't look like the Fed is going to capitulate any time soon. So what is the market need to see?

HOOPER: Well, the market needs to see some Fed action and other central bank action that suggest they're starting to at least take their foot off the accelerator. It's not just the Fed we have to worry about. It's also the ECB.

WEISENTHAL: Right.

HOOPER: Keep in mind, we've got a lot of too political risk and they suggest that they're going to continue to go forward with the plan to end tapering at the end of this year. I would expect that at some point if the situation worsens that these two major central banks do try to get a little bit more dovish.

WEISENTHAL: Other big story obviously the election coming up in a week from tomorrow. How much is that sort of dominating what people are interested in as far as your interaction with people on the terminal and stuff like that?

(BREAK)

ABRAMOWICZ: Kristina, real quick, are you advising that your clients hold a little bit more cash if they can?

HOOPER: Well, if they have dry powder this maybe a good time to actually deploy it. But what we are advising is actually to be incredibly well diversified. So have exposure outside the U.S. and broadly outside the U.S., also have adequate exposure to alternatives because historically, they've had a lower correlation to equities.

ABRAMOWICZ: Like?

HOOPER: Like for example gold, real estate and market mutual funds.

ABRAMOWICZ: Kristina Hooper, thank you so much. Really interesting insight. Thank you so much. Kristina Hooper, Invesco Chief Global Strategist and Mike Regan, Bloomberg Markets live editor.

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5TM7-6J21-JBHT-D38T-00000-00Kristina Hooper is interviewed on BB TV2018-10-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:06:21ZLexisNexisKristina Hooper is interviewed on BB TVWalthamFULL TEXT

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

LISA ABRAMOWICZ, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Let's bring in Kristina Hooper, Invesco Global Chief Market Strategist.

Kristina, what you make of today's sell-off and does it give you a sense that we're not done here with the pain?

KRISTINA HOOPER, CHIEF GLOBAL MARKET STRATEGIST, INVESCO: I haven't expected this to be done and this just confirms that. We've got a lot of trepidations going into midterm elections. And to that, we've had a lot of other unresolved issues, from Brexit to the Italian fiscal situation. We've added some risks in there in terms of Angela Merkel's resignation.

There's a lot going on. And of course a pervasive weight on market is concerns about trade and as well as Fed tightening and neither both have gone away.

JOE WEISENTHAL, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Are there any opportunities here that when you look down at all this like sort of wall of worry that you're describing, all these chaos, are there areas that the market that are standing out is like, OK, this is getting a little much.

HOOPER: Absolutely. And the sell-off in tech has been overdone. There's a lot of concern, whispers that if we see a Democratic House there could be greater regulation on tech. And I think that's fueling some of the concerns around tech.

ABRAMOWICZ: And the U.K. budget today that they're going to be taxing some of the big tech companies.

HOOPER: Absolutely. And so that has weighed down on tech but that's where we can get some pretty significant secular growth.

WEISENTHAL: I just think it's worth pointing out, we're not even down that much anymore. We've had a pretty nice bounce, S&P down 0.6%, Dow 1%. Still deeply red but clearly off the worst levels from literally just when I got on.

ABRAMOWICZ: Well, and that's my question, Mike, to you. Are we just seeing Argos going wild?

(BREAK)

CAROLINE HYDE, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: And, Kristina, you were just saying that you weren't expecting this bouncing off these days anytime, but we do have a divided market voice here at the moment. We have Goldman Sachs saying, hey, stop buying. The valuations got too eroded here. And then we have Morgan Stanley saying, you know, sell every rally. Where do you sit on the spectrum?

HOOPER: I sit in a very neutral place and that I have a long-term time horizon.

HYDE: In Switzerland.

HOOPER: I think you could say. I have a very long-term time horizon and we encourage our investors to have very long time horizons. And in that environment, certainly, there are opportunities to be tactical and pick up some bargains but certainly there's no place for a wholesale removal from this market.

WEISENTHAL: We thought we're going to be talking about the big story of the day which was IBM buying Red Hat. And the sympathy trade with a bunch of tech, all those sort of arrays, but what do you make of like big juicy M&A deals like that people say about the whole space?

(BREAK)

HYDE: Let's get back to Kristina Hooper of Invesco and Bloomberg's Mike Regan.

Kristina, I want to get your sense and perspective on what it means for China for you at the moment because this is what sent off lower was the concern that tariffs could be ramping up once again?

HOOPER: And I think that's absolutely what we still be concerned about. In fact, I would take the news this morning that China was cutting auto taxes is actually a negative 2. Because that's one more stimulative act that they've done from cutting rates to devaluating the yuan to essentially supported economy. That tells me they're hunkering down and getting ready for a full-blown trade war, including the talks they've just had with Japan. This is not intended to be -- they don't expect to capitulate from everything I'm seeing. And so I would expect the trade talk to be unsuccessful next month and for us to go into more full blown trade wars.

WEISENTHAL: Speaking of capitulation when do we start seeing the market or the Fed or the market's perception of the Fed come down with respect to the pace of rate hikes?

HOOPER: Well, we need to hear some messaging from the Fed because keep in mind, last week, we continued to hear full speed ahead. Although the Loretta Mester did give us a bit of an out and said, well, essentially we're still data dependent so we could change course.

So I think we need to listen to messaging from the Fed and also of course follow the economic data. For example the jobs report this week. If we have an easing in wage growth it remains very modest, then that gives the Fed a bit more flexibility to take its foot off the accelerator.

ABRAMOWICZ: You know, I have to wonder too, Joe's point though, about interest rates. Interestingly, on this risk off day, yet again, we see 10- year yields and the two-year yields and the day slighter higher which indicates that we are not going to the haven type of asset class and should be somewhat unnerving. And I have to wonder, you know, Caroline, you point to the trade tensions, but how much of this really underneath is a rate- hiking story. And I wonder what you're hearing, Mike, from your sources.

(BREAK)

ABRAMOWICZ: Hold on one second. Kristina, do you buy this? Do you buy that this is just like rebalancing issue or do you think this is real sort of higher rates.

HOOPER: I do think this is a higher rate issue. Although it is combined with a trade issue because trade is finally getting tangible. So really it's in Switzerland.

HYDE: Oh, Kristina, what about the dollar? How much of this is a concerned about the dollar story we're hearing in earnings now, how much and what's falling on the back that we worried about dollar strength?

HOOPER: Well, the dollar is so interrelated with the Fed story, right? Because the closest correlation with the dollar going higher is expectations about Fed's fund rate. So it's all interconnected. And certainly trade has played a role in boosting the dollar as well.

WEISENTHAL: OK. So what's going to turn the market around? What is the market looking for? Earnings, it doesn't really seem to be doing it. Do you think the trade war is going it get worse? It doesn't look like the Fed is going to capitulate any time soon. So what is the market need to see?

HOOPER: Well, the market needs to see some Fed action and other central bank action that suggest they're starting to at least take their foot off the accelerator. It's not just the Fed we have to worry about. It's also the ECB.

WEISENTHAL: Right.

HOOPER: Keep in mind, we've got a lot of too political risk and they suggest that they're going to continue to go forward with the plan to end tapering at the end of this year. I would expect that at some point if the situation worsens that these two major central banks do try to get a little bit more dovish.

WEISENTHAL: Other big story obviously the election coming up in a week from tomorrow. How much is that sort of dominating what people are interested in as far as your interaction with people on the terminal and stuff like that?

(BREAK)

ABRAMOWICZ: Kristina, real quick, are you advising that your clients hold a little bit more cash if they can?

HOOPER: Well, if they have dry powder this maybe a good time to actually deploy it. But what we are advising is actually to be incredibly well diversified. So have exposure outside the U.S. and broadly outside the U.S., also have adequate exposure to alternatives because historically, they've had a lower correlation to equities.

ABRAMOWICZ: Like?

HOOPER: Like for example gold, real estate and market mutual funds.

ABRAMOWICZ: Kristina Hooper, thank you so much. Really interesting insight. Thank you so much. Kristina Hooper, Invesco Chief Global Strategist and Mike Regan, Bloomberg Markets live editor.

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

urn:contentItem:5TM1-V0Y1-JB20-G0HN-00000-00Kristina Hooper is interviewed on BB TV2018-10-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:06:21ZLexisNexisBLOOMBERG TV12:00 AM ESTKristina Hooper, Joe Weisenthal, Caroline HydeNEWSInternational102980cb.550Kristina Hooper is interviewed on BB TVLisa Abramowicz

Kristina Hooper discusses politics

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

LISA ABRAMOWICZ, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Let's bring in Kristina Hooper, Invesco Global Chief Market Strategist.

Kristina, what you make of today's sell-off and does it give you a sense that we're not done here with the pain?

KRISTINA HOOPER, CHIEF GLOBAL MARKET STRATEGIST, INVESCO: I haven't expected this to be done and this just confirms that. We've got a lot of trepidations going into midterm elections. And to that, we've had a lot of other unresolved issues, from Brexit to the Italian fiscal situation. We've added some risks in there in terms of Angela Merkel's resignation.

There's a lot going on. And of course a pervasive weight on market is concerns about trade and as well as Fed tightening and neither both have gone away.

JOE WEISENTHAL, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Are there any opportunities here that when you look down at all this like sort of wall of worry that you're describing, all these chaos, are there areas that the market that are standing out is like, OK, this is getting a little much.

HOOPER: Absolutely. And the sell-off in tech has been overdone. There's a lot of concern, whispers that if we see a Democratic House there could be greater regulation on tech. And I think that's fueling some of the concerns around tech.

ABRAMOWICZ: And the U.K. budget today that they're going to be taxing some of the big tech companies.

HOOPER: Absolutely. And so that has weighed down on tech but that's where we can get some pretty significant secular growth.

WEISENTHAL: I just think it's worth pointing out, we're not even down that much anymore. We've had a pretty nice bounce, S&P down 0.6%, Dow 1%. Still deeply red but clearly off the worst levels from literally just when I got on.

ABRAMOWICZ: Well, and that's my question, Mike, to you. Are we just seeing Argos going wild?

(BREAK)

CAROLINE HYDE, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: And, Kristina, you were just saying that you weren't expecting this bouncing off these days anytime, but we do have a divided market voice here at the moment. We have Goldman Sachs saying, hey, stop buying. The valuations got too eroded here. And then we have Morgan Stanley saying, you know, sell every rally. Where do you sit on the spectrum?

HOOPER: I sit in a very neutral place and that I have a long-term time horizon.

HYDE: In Switzerland.

HOOPER: I think you could say. I have a very long-term time horizon and we encourage our investors to have very long time horizons. And in that environment, certainly, there are opportunities to be tactical and pick up some bargains but certainly there's no place for a wholesale removal from this market.

WEISENTHAL: We thought we're going to be talking about the big story of the day which was IBM buying Red Hat. And the sympathy trade with a bunch of tech, all those sort of arrays, but what do you make of like big juicy M&A deals like that people say about the whole space?

(BREAK)

HYDE: Let's get back to Kristina Hooper of Invesco and Bloomberg's Mike Regan.

Kristina, I want to get your sense and perspective on what it means for China for you at the moment because this is what sent off lower was the concern that tariffs could be ramping up once again?

HOOPER: And I think that's absolutely what we still be concerned about. In fact, I would take the news this morning that China was cutting auto taxes is actually a negative 2. Because that's one more stimulative act that they've done from cutting rates to devaluating the yuan to essentially supported economy. That tells me they're hunkering down and getting ready for a full-blown trade war, including the talks they've just had with Japan. This is not intended to be -- they don't expect to capitulate from everything I'm seeing. And so I would expect the trade talk to be unsuccessful next month and for us to go into more full blown trade wars.

WEISENTHAL: Speaking of capitulation when do we start seeing the market or the Fed or the market's perception of the Fed come down with respect to the pace of rate hikes?

HOOPER: Well, we need to hear some messaging from the Fed because keep in mind, last week, we continued to hear full speed ahead. Although the Loretta Mester did give us a bit of an out and said, well, essentially we're still data dependent so we could change course.

So I think we need to listen to messaging from the Fed and also of course follow the economic data. For example the jobs report this week. If we have an easing in wage growth it remains very modest, then that gives the Fed a bit more flexibility to take its foot off the accelerator.

ABRAMOWICZ: You know, I have to wonder too, Joe's point though, about interest rates. Interestingly, on this risk off day, yet again, we see 10- year yields and the two-year yields and the day slighter higher which indicates that we are not going to the haven type of asset class and should be somewhat unnerving. And I have to wonder, you know, Caroline, you point to the trade tensions, but how much of this really underneath is a rate- hiking story. And I wonder what you're hearing, Mike, from your sources.

(BREAK)

ABRAMOWICZ: Hold on one second. Kristina, do you buy this? Do you buy that this is just like rebalancing issue or do you think this is real sort of higher rates.

HOOPER: I do think this is a higher rate issue. Although it is combined with a trade issue because trade is finally getting tangible. So really it's in Switzerland.

HYDE: Oh, Kristina, what about the dollar? How much of this is a concerned about the dollar story we're hearing in earnings now, how much and what's falling on the back that we worried about dollar strength?

HOOPER: Well, the dollar is so interrelated with the Fed story, right? Because the closest correlation with the dollar going higher is expectations about Fed's fund rate. So it's all interconnected. And certainly trade has played a role in boosting the dollar as well.

WEISENTHAL: OK. So what's going to turn the market around? What is the market looking for? Earnings, it doesn't really seem to be doing it. Do you think the trade war is going it get worse? It doesn't look like the Fed is going to capitulate any time soon. So what is the market need to see?

HOOPER: Well, the market needs to see some Fed action and other central bank action that suggest they're starting to at least take their foot off the accelerator. It's not just the Fed we have to worry about. It's also the ECB.

WEISENTHAL: Right.

HOOPER: Keep in mind, we've got a lot of too political risk and they suggest that they're going to continue to go forward with the plan to end tapering at the end of this year. I would expect that at some point if the situation worsens that these two major central banks do try to get a little bit more dovish.

WEISENTHAL: Other big story obviously the election coming up in a week from tomorrow. How much is that sort of dominating what people are interested in as far as your interaction with people on the terminal and stuff like that?

(BREAK)

ABRAMOWICZ: Kristina, real quick, are you advising that your clients hold a little bit more cash if they can?

HOOPER: Well, if they have dry powder this maybe a good time to actually deploy it. But what we are advising is actually to be incredibly well diversified. So have exposure outside the U.S. and broadly outside the U.S., also have adequate exposure to alternatives because historically, they've had a lower correlation to equities.

ABRAMOWICZ: Like?

HOOPER: Like for example gold, real estate and market mutual funds.

ABRAMOWICZ: Kristina Hooper, thank you so much. Really interesting insight. Thank you so much. Kristina Hooper, Invesco Chief Global Strategist and Mike Regan, Bloomberg Markets live editor.

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5603-BFF1-DYTP-W4CM-00000-00KRX to attract big tech firms to minor bourse2012-06-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:06:21ZLexisNexisKRX to attract big tech firms to minor bourseBy Kim Jae-won

Korea Exchange (KRX) said Tuesday that it will seek to attract big technology companies to the KOSDAQ to invigorate the minor bourse which has suffered from a lack of interest from foreign and institutional investors.

The state-run securities agency said that it will follow the NASDAQ model which has been successful by luring large-scale renowned technology firms such as Apple, Googleand Facebook.

Analysts say this is part of the agency's efforts to boost the market as it would benefit from the inclusion of some big players. The absence of trademark companies deters institutional and foreign investors.

'We will spare no efforts to attract big-sized high-end technology companies. We hope the newcomers will energize the market,' said Kim Bong-soo, head of the bourse operator.

The secondary KOSADAQ will opt to embrace more firms for listing, targeting those with cutting-edge technology and substantial potential to grow but which are short of capital, it said.

The market will focus to list blue-chip, IT-related public companies or foreign firms and develop relevant indices to attract investors, according to the KRX.

The plan comes after the country's financial regulator recently announced it is preparing to launch a new stock market for small and mid-sized companies.

In early April, the Financial Supervisory Service, the country's financial watchdog, said it is in the process of opening the Korea New Exchange (KONEX) within this year to better support smaller firms raise capital.

While the country's main stock market will continue to rely on medium and large cap firms, the KOSDAQ and the KONEX will serve to foster the growth of small and mid-sized companies, the KRX said.

With such a three-track initiative, the stock markets will hope for more balanced growth and enhance sales, and investment from institutional investors here and abroad, the bourse operator added.

The tech-laden KOSDAQ first opened in 1996 in Korea in the wake of a boom in the information technology sector, but its size has dwindled to a market cap of less than 3 percent of the KOSPI as of the end of last year.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WCB-7RV1-JDJN-64D1-00000-00KT edit: FB's digital currency is a smart idea, but can we trust it?2019-06-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:06:21ZLexisNexisKT edit: FB's digital currency is a smart idea, but can we trust it?

If Facebook is able to influence the use of Libra over other payment methods, it could disrupt the financial world.

Fifteen years ago Facebook unleashed a social revolution by creating a virtual world with no boundaries. Since then it has changed the way we connect, interact, and conduct business. More than 2.7 billion users access the network every month, making it a truly global platform with unprecedented reach. So every time Mark Zukerberg and his team make changes to the site, people sit up and take notice. On Tuesday, Facebook unveiled its plan to launch a block chain-based digital currency, Libra, by 2020. It is being dubbed as a stable coin, a term that means the currency will be pegged to real assets and fiat currencies resulting in less volatility, unlike a host of cryptocurrencies that have suffered a great deal of volatility in their prices.

If Facebook is able to influence the use of Libra over other payment methods, it could disrupt the financial world. Facebook has the reach and the numbers to make this venture successful. In fact, it could reach out to a large population that has access to the Internet (and hence Facebook) but not to banks or other financial services. What should worry us however is the lack of rules and regulations by governments. Central banks haven't kept pace with the innovation fintech has rolled out, just as digital regulation hasn't kept pace with Big Tech's plans. Fee-less currency transfers will increase competition and reduce the costs of cross-country transfers further. We have come a long way since the introduction of MasterCard and Visa gateways in 1970s. With the arrival of PayPal and e-wallets like Beam, Apple Pay and Google Pay, mean we see less of the fiat currencies like dirhams, dollars, pounds. Facebook's digital currency has big potential and is being backed by financial biggies like PayPal, MasterCard, Visa, Lyft. Yet, Facebook's ability to protect the interests of its users has been debatable. Central banks and governments need to put in place rules to ensure Big Tech companies like Facebook do not control our financial lives through digital currencies. We need to build trust into the financial digital ecosystem before it's too late.

urn:contentItem:60C2-TS61-JDJN-63FR-00000-00KT edit: Google expands reach, gains from tech nationalism2020-07-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:06:21ZLexisNexisKT edit: Google expands reach, gains from tech nationalism

Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi talking to Google CEO Sundar Pichai and team through video conferencing in New Delhi.

(ANI)

Access to a large untapped digital market is a goldmine for any tech firm. A perfect example of this is the rise of Alibaba Group and Tencent in China that have grown exponentially with a wide array of offerings. The two giants have innovated and catered to the needs of more than a billion users in China. The experience has been rewarding and the range and quality of services offered by these Chinese firms are second to none. American firms, especially Google, have long tried to get a larger pie of Chinese users but protectionist policies of the Chinese government haven't allowed it to gain a foothold in the country. Google is shut out of China and with the passage of the new security law last month, it faces the prospect of greater difficulty in operating in Hong Kong. The tech giant is now looking to tap into the next, or perhaps the last great untapped digital market in the world - India. Its decision to invest $10 billion in the country over the next seven years is significant in these times. Over half of India's over 1.3 billion population does not have access to the Internet, which makes it a fertile ground for technology companies from all over the world.


Google's investment in India is timely, which could have a significant impact on various sectors in the country such as banking, health, agriculture, digital commerce, and online education that are looking for a digital facelift to realise their potential. However, this opportunity should be complemented with some changes in the the country's tax regime and more investment in warehousing network which is key to e-commerce logistics and the agriculture industry. Moreover, as Big Tech gets stronger, it is also a moment of reckoning for governments. There should be a parallel debate on how data would be harvested, used, and protected. What sort of an impact will Google's large presence have on local innovation? Will it kill competition or energise it? Google, for instance, has already invested in a number of companies in India - a large number of them start-ups. Its latest investment could give it a firm foothold in India. For the tech behemoth, the country offers plenty of opportunities for growth after its losses in China. As for regulations, the Indian government should frame laws that ensure the privacy of its citizens is protected and is not misused by Big Tech and other digital companies.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WN1-6CC1-F11P-X1VP-00000-00KT Edit: Has Big Tech gone out of control?2019-07-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:06:21ZLexisNexisKT Edit: Has Big Tech gone out of control?

Technology is fine as long as humans govern it. Allowing Big Tech to determine the future of humankind would mean walking into a civilisational trap.

Big Tech has grown at a mind-boggling pace in just two decades. The companies leading the charge have not only become an integral part of our lives but are also pervasive, stealthily influencing the choices we make. What to read, watch, eat, listen to - Big Tech is good at suggestions, it lures us into its ecosystem. Now there are fears that Big Tech has grown too big for Big Governments. The US Department of Justice has, therefore, announced a broad antitrust investigation into its functioning. Even though the scope of the investigation will cover only the American landscape, the findings could give us a broader perspective on how technology is influencing our lives and how we are living by virtual terms set by them. Consider this: Google was formed in 1998; and Facebook in 2004. Today, Google performs nine out of every 10 online searches worldwide. And Facebook has connected well over two billion users and become the most popular social media network. The two firms together have taken over more than half the online advertising market.

The questions we need to ask are these: Have these firms engaged in practices that have reduced competition? Has their growing dominance stifled innovation? And what has been the impact on us consumers, who have been happy with the low prices of products and convenience of using them but could be selling our lives to these companies. The Federal Trade Commission recently fined Facebook for $5 billion. The EU has fined Google for $1.7 billion for illegally using its dominant position for online search adverts. Facebook now plans to launch its digital currency, Libra, which could be the biggest disrupter in global finance. Governments and regulators have clearly not kept pace with the speed of innovation in the tech sphere but this investigation should lead to concrete measures that protect users. Checks and balances on big technology companies are essential. Europe's General Data Protection Regulation was a great start, and the US could take a leaf out of Europe's book. Technology is fine as long as humans govern it. Allowing Big Tech to determine the future of humankind would mean walking into a civilisational trap.
